Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Surface Integrity induced by Cryogenic Processing of Biomaterials for Improved Functional Performance

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for research on quantitative understanding of the integrity of surfaced produced by cryogenic processing of metallic biomaterials during severe plastic deformation (SPD) processes. Engineered surface layers will be produced in selected biomaterials, with preferred nano/ultrafine grain structures, increased hardness and compressive residual stresses, etc., for improved functional performance in biomedical implants and other manufactured components. Cryogenic machining and burnishing processes will be developed to produce surface layers with nano/ultrafine grain structures in selected biomaterials to provide improved wear and corrosion resistance, and compressive residual stresses to offer greater fatigue life. Major project tasks are: (1) Systematic experimental study of the integrity of surfaced produced by cryogenic processes to establish the influence of processing parameters on hardness, grain size and residual stresses; (2) Testing of cryogenically-processed components to quantify performance improvement, especially corrosion and wear resistance and fatigue life; (3) Development of hybrid predictive performance models using numerical and analytical methods; (4) Development of optimization methods for performance improvement; and (5) Model validation and refinement.

If successful, this project will lead to predictive performance models for novel cryogenic manufacturing processes to provide optimal process parameters for producing functionally-superior products from biomaterials. Improved wear and corrosion resistance and enhanced fatigue life are among the most desirable product performance measures expected from optimally designed and performed cryogenic processes. Optimally produced superhard surface layers from cryogenic processing will have the potential to replace hard coating in some applications. The anticipated project findings will also have the potential for producing components in other manufacturing applications for improved performance and life, especially in aerospace and automotive sectors. Significant health and environmental benefits can also be achieved from the implementation of cryogenic processes, which are clean, toxic-free, and pose no adverse health effects.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at developing quantitative understanding of the effect of cryogenic processing of metallic biomaterials on surface/surface integrity and quality improvements with the long-term objective of improving the functional performance of biomedical implants made from these materials.  The project involved the following specific activities:

  • Extensive experimental study covering analysis of changes in hardness (influencing wear resistance), corrosion rate (influencing the corrosion resistance) microstructure (influencing mechanical properties) and residual stresses (influencing the fatigue life).
  • Analytical/numerical modeling of machining processes to predict machining performance measures/parameters such as cutting forces and induced material properties such as microstructures (including grain size, affected layer thickness, hardness, stresses, strains, etc.).
  • Validation of the model

 

Key outcomes of the project are:

  • Cryogenic machining produces a superior and significantly improved surface roughness in comparison with dry machining and machining with flood cooling (Figure 1).
  • Cryogenic machining produces significantly higher hardness in the machined surface layer compared with dry machining. Also, a much deeper hardened surface layer is produced in cryogenic machining (Figure 2).
  • A narrow, grain-refined severe plastically deformed (SPD) layer (about 35 - 75 micron thickness) was produced in cryogenic machining under all conditions tested. In comparison, dry machining produced about 2 - 4 times smaller layers in thickness (Figure 3).
  • A thin layer with nano-grains was formed on the surface of Ti-6Al-7Nb alloy during the machining process. The grain size measured within the top SPD layer from cryogenic machined samples are in the range of 30 to 40 nm, which is much smaller than those from dry machined samples (Figure 4).
  • The calculated average grain size from XRD analysis shows that the gain size in cryogenic machining was in the range of 16.4 – 20.7 nm, while the dry machining produced a much larger range, between 19.2 – 31.2 nm (Figure 5).
  • Compressive residual stresses were induced under cryogenic machining from machined surface (up to 250 μm depth in tangential direction, and 320 μm in axial direction). Also the magnitudes of these compressive residual stresses are much larger in cryogenic machining compared with dry machining.
  • Corrosion tests show that the rate of corrosion in cryogenic machining was about 25 – 42% less that what was measured in dry machining.
  • Predicted values of machining performance variables are in close agreement with experimental values (Figure 6).

The project also offered significant work experience and training for students on the use of experimental equipment, processing and analysis of results and report writing.

The project resulted in several publications and technical presentations at international conferences, and helped to update some of the course offerings at the University of Kentucky. Also, one IP disclosure document has been produced.  

A short course has also been developed for delivery to industry groups presenting the new findings from this project that has significant application potential.

Modified by: Ibrahim S Jawahir

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project was aimed at developing quantitative understanding of the effect of cryogenic processing of metallic biomaterials on surface/surface integrity and quality improvements with the long-term objective of improving the functional performance of biomedical implants made from these materials. The project involved the following specific activities: Extensive experimental study covering analysis of changes in hardness (influencing wear resistance), corrosion rate (influencing the corrosion resistance) microstructure (influencing mechanical properties) and residual stresses (influencing the fatigue life). Analytical/numerical modeling of machining processes to predict machining performance measures/parameters such as cutting forces and induced material properties such as microstructures (including grain size, affected layer thickness, hardness, stresses, strains, etc.). Validation of the model Key outcomes of the project are: Cryogenic machining produces a superior and significantly improved surface roughness in comparison with dry machining and machining with flood cooling (Figure 1). Cryogenic machining produces significantly higher hardness in the machined surface layer compared with dry machining. Also, a much deeper hardened surface layer is produced in cryogenic machining (Figure 2). A narrow, grain-refined severe plastically deformed (SPD) layer (about 35 - 75 micron thickness) was produced in cryogenic machining under all conditions tested. In comparison, dry machining produced about 2 - 4 times smaller layers in thickness (Figure 3). A thin layer with nano-grains was formed on the surface of Ti-6Al-7Nb alloy during the machining process. The grain size measured within the top SPD layer from cryogenic machined samples are in the range of 30 to 40 nm, which is much smaller than those from dry machined samples (Figure 4). The calculated average grain size from XRD analysis shows that the gain size in cryogenic machining was in the range of 16.4 – 20.7 nm, while the dry machining produced a much larger range, between 19.2 – 31.2 nm (Figure 5). Compressive residual stresses were induced under cryogenic machining from machined surface (up to 250 μm depth in tangential direction, and 320 μm in axial direction). Also the magnitudes of these compressive residual stresses are much larger in cryogenic machining compared with dry machining. Corrosion tests show that the rate of corrosion in cryogenic machining was about 25 – 42% less that what was measured in dry machining. Predicted values of machining performance variables are in close agreement with experimental values (Figure 6). The project also offered significant work experience and training for students on the use of experimental equipment, processing and analysis of results and report writing. The project resulted in several publications and technical presentations at international conferences, and helped to update some of the course offerings at the University of Kentucky. Also, one IP disclosure document has been produced. A short course has also been developed for delivery to industry groups presenting the new findings from this project that has significant application potential.
